Dialogue of the Creatures: Concerning the Leopard and Unicorn, who fight the Dragon, the 88th dialogue

app.lem: Dialogus Creaturum: De leopardo et unicorni, qui pugnabant cum dracone, dial. 88.
app.rdg: Dialogue of the Creatures: Concerning the Leopard and Unicorn, who fight the Dragon, the 88th dialogue

app.lem: Leopardus, ut Solmus dicit, animal est generatum ex leone et pardo. Horum feuvinae sunt audaciores et fortiores maribus.
app.rdg: The leopard, as Solinus says, was made from the lion and the pard, the panther. Its females are braver and stronger than the males.

app.lem: Plinius : aliquis volens resistere leopardis furentibus, fricet allia inter manus, nee mora, leopardus resiliet nec resistet, quia odorem allii sustinere non potest.
app.rdg: Someone who desires to stand against raging leopards should--without hesitating--rub garlic cloves between his hands. The leopard will retreat, and yield, since he cannot bear the odor of garlic. So says Plinius.

app.lem: Leopardus subrufum colorem habet, maculas per totum nigras; niulto minores sunt quam leoues.
app.rdg: The leopard is a ginger color, and black spots cover it whole. Leopards are much smaller than lions.

app.lem: Leopardus, quando comedit aliquod venenum, stercus hominis quserit, quod comedit, et sanatur. Ambrosius.
app.rdg: If a leopard eats poison, it will seek out a man’s ordure, which it then consumes and is healed by. Thus Ambrose.

app.lem: Hæ bestiæ sunt crudelissimæ naturaliter, ita quod sic domesticari non possunt, ut obliviscantur crudelitatis suæ. Domesticantur tamen ad venandum.
app.rdg: These beasts are, by their nature, most cruel, and they cannot be tamed to forget their cruelness. However, they are trained to hunt. When, in the course of a chase, one is led to some prey, he will grow calm.

app.lem: Igitur dum ad praadamin venatione dueuntur, relaxantur, quam si quarto aut quinto saltu non potest capere, subsistit iratus fortiter,
app.rdg: But if he cannot seize the prey in four or five leaps, he stops, profoundly angered.

app.lem: et nisi statim venator furenti bestiae aliquam bestiam offerat, cujus sanguine placetur, irruit in venatorem vel quoseunque obvios, quia impossibile est placari eum nisi in sanguine.
app.rdg: And unless a hunter offers some animal to the furious beast, to placate him with its blood, he charges the hunter or whatever else he meets on the way. A leopard is impossible to soothe except with blood.

app.lem: Hic pugnabat cum dracone, sed non prsevalebat, propter quod ad unicornem perrexit et humiliter ipsum obsecravit dicens : eminens es ac virtuosus et doctus belli, peto obnixe, quod me defendas a furore draconis.
app.rdg: A Leopard, long ago, fought with a Dragon, but he did not prevail. So he headed to the Unicorn and humbly entreated him, saying, “You are lofty, and virtuous, and learned in war. I beseech you, my sometime enemy, to defend me from Dragon’s madness.”

app.lem: Unicornis autem se sublimare cœpit et audiens de se talia dici ait : verum dicis , quia doctus sum prœlii, propterea optime defensabo te, noli pavere, cum enim aperiet draco os suum, in gutture ipsum cornu perforabo.
app.rdg: Unicorn began to rise and, hearing himself spoken of so, said, “You speak truly, since I am battle-wise, and I shall protect you best. Do not tremble, for when Dragon opens his mouth I will pierce his throat with my horn.”

app.lem: Cum autem ad draconem pariter venissent, leopardus bellum initiavit sperans de auxilio unicornis.
app.rdg: They went to Dragon together, and Leopard began the war, expecting Unicorn’s help.

app.lem: Draco vero certavit adversus eos et ignern et feetorem ex ore emittebat, sed cum os aperiret, unicornis quam citius cueurrit volens ipsum in gutture transvibrare,
app.rdg: Dragon truly strove against them, and spat fire and vapor against them. But, when he opened his mouth, Unicorn raced at him as swiftly as he could, aiming to pierce his throat through.

app.lem: draco vero agitavit caput et unicornis cornu in terram fixit dicens moriendo : qui pro alio vult pugnare, cupit se trucidare.
app.rdg: But Dragon shook his head, and drove Unicorn’s horn into the earth, saying to him as he died on the spot,

app.lem: Sic enim stultum est, de se confidere ac de quo sibi non pertinet agonizare.
app.rdg: “He who desires to fight for another desires to slay himself. It is foolish to be so assured of oneself, and to fight over that which does not afflict you.”

app.lem: Unde Eccl. XI: de ea re, quæ te non molestat, ne certaveris.
app.rdg: Indeed, so says Ecclesiastes XI, “do not fight on account of that which does not vex you.”

app.lem: Ergo require in animo tuo a te ipso, quis es, quid facere vis, utrum factum illud ad te pertineat. Ad minus ad alium te immiscere non debes.
app.rdg: Demand of yourself in your mind who you are, what you desire to do, what deed itself is yours, for you must not confuse yourself with another.

app.lem: Noli pro alio pugnare nee inter discordantes discordiam augere, sed fac , ut dicit Seneca: semper dissensio ab alio ineipiat, a te reconciliatio.
app.rdg: Do not fight for another, and do not augment strife among the striving. “But make it thus, that conflict is begun by another, and reconciliation begun by you.” So says Seneca.

app.lem: Quidam bellantes aggressi sunt inimicum, sed alius quidam cueurrit volens ipsum defendere et armavit se versus inimicos illius.
app.rdg: Once some warring men attacked an enemy. Another hastened to him, wanting only to defend him, and took up arms against the man’s enemies.

app.lem: Illi autem dixerunt: amice, tibi injuriam non faeimus, tolle quod tuum est et vade , quoniam de inimico nostro vindictam quærimus.
app.rdg: But the warring men said, “friend, we shall do no injury to you. Take what is yours and depart, for we seek vengeance only from our enemy.”

app.lem: Qui non acquiescens sermonibus eorum ad bellum contra eos se paravit. Illi autem indignati cum inimico ipsum mutilaverunt.
app.rdg: The man, not listening to the word of the preachers, prepared himself for war against the attackers. Scorned, they slew him with their enemy.

app.lem: Iste ergo liber dyalogus creaturarum appellatus sic materias iocundas fingit ut morum gravitas et aptitudo doctrine per sanctorum auctoritates doctorum exornetur habens duas tabulas prenotates +
app.rdg: Therefore, this book, called The Dialogue of Creatures, which consists of two marked sections, crafts pleasant matters in order to, with the authority of the learned saints, embellish customs’ gravity and increase doctrine’s aptitude.

app.lem: Quarum prima exprimit de quibus creaturis tractant singuli dyalogorum ut lector quo citius habeat circa que versatureius intencio
app.rdg: The first sections speaks about the creatures that each of the dialogues discusses, so that the reader might possess those things faster around which the dialogue’s intention moves.

app.lem: Secunda tabula alphabetica ordine generaliter singulas materias virtutum et viciorum ad mores componen dos et corrigendos predicatorem et inquirentem docet + Que scilicet cuilibet narracioni sibi in processu sermonum convenire possunt +
app.rdg: . The second section, in alphabetical order, demonstrates to preachers and seekers single matters of virtue and vice in order to assemble and correct customs.
